I'm never disappointed with crash course videos, but... I thought this said AC Circus and I have to admit, knowing what might have been has really limited how happy I can be.

When you said that the inductor produces an emf in the opposite direction of the current, what you meant to say was that it is in the opposite direction of the "change" in current.  Also, when you talked about removing a battery in a circuit with an inductor, what you meant to say was replacing the battery with a short circuit.  If you just remove the battery, and leave it as an open circuit, very bad things will happen, as the inductor tries to push a current through the open circuit, thereby generating a very high voltage.  Of course, I know what you meant with your statements, as will most people who are familiar with topic.  Though, I think the way it was worded may create some confusion for people who are being exposed to this for the first time.

there is something that I don't understand, there are two(emf)s in the circuit with the inductor, the original and the induced , did we add them up or what ?

Rofaida Elsayed   No we dont add them. The induced emf is generated whenevr there is a change in cutrent. After that its not there... i mean the barrier that inductor creates to  prevent the "Flow of changing current" is vanished as soon as the current gets constant
Karan Dosanjh  not if we're talking about  alternating current, it keeps changing so we have 2( emf )s now
Rofaida Elsayed you are right about “Ac as changing current”. I wonder what might be the answer then Anyway, if you got it let me know please

Rofaida Elsayed But they are talking about this while taking a Battery 🤔.... even Eugene took the cade of battery.... so that means the current only changes when switching on and switching off. Just these 2 instants
Karan Dosanjh  I know that but  when it's AC current the current changes instantaneously and continuously so there is always an induced emf that is proportional to the rate of charge of the current

Rofaida Elsayed Ohh now i remember. I am in 12th grade and i remember now that during our lectures on ‘Reluctances applied by capacitors and inductors’ in full LCR circuits, we derived a relation of Xc(reluctance by capacitor to current)= 1/C ω and XL(reluctance applied by inductor to current)= L ω  So when ω is too large(which is the case of AC) the reluctance by inductor would be so large that the current is blocked in AC  And when current is DC the ω is zero and hence negligible or no reluctance by inductor so DC is allowed
Karan Dosanjh I'm in 12th grade too, in our curriculum they don't explain how these Xl an Xc were derived,  they should take the induced  emf into account but I want to know how, I want details
@Karan Dosanjh I think you meant to say "reactance", not "reluctance"
Macieks300 ahh yes... Thanks for tue correction

Rofaida Elsayed The Induced emf just happens in AC. And while the inductor blocks AC , its not of any use (although i am pretty sure they are used in home appliances but i dont know how they could be used with AC in homes)  But the thing is the use of inductors , as we 12th graders should know is through DC it is allowed and no opposite emf is generated  FOR DETAILS— see the formula .... XL= L ω ω is the frequency at which the AC current is sent through the circuit.  And ONLY AC CURRENT has a frequency. DC does not have a frequency and so is constant.   You can figure out from this that Reactance is Huge in AC and so it is blocked and and so emf produced is equal to emf applied. (I think you got your answer)  While DC has zero frequency and so Reactance is zero and so current flows freely Reactance is kind of a Resistance.   If you wanna know the derivation of Reactances then connect me on social media through instagram and snapchat ——   deepsingh_20    Or through whatsapp +91 8054741577 ... i will show you the photo of derivations

Karan Dosanjh  they say the voltage is 90 degrees ahead of the current , what voltage are they talking about ? The voltage from the source  or the actual voltage across the solenoid , I still don't know whether we add the emfs up or what (in an AC circuit) .....I'm missing something
Karan Dosanjh also I already understand the things you mentioned in your comment , this is not what I'm asking about

Rofaida Elsayed  Yeah we add them up.   The scenario is- We connect a battery and an inductor. We switch the circuit on. Current BEGINS to flow in circuit. As the rate of flow of current is increasing the back emf is generated.   Yes, WE ADD THEM UP and so it is seen that the current is opposed by inductor and the opposition is EQUAL. It is only when the current is constant, the opposition emf vanishes as there is no rate of change of current.

Rofaida Elsayed AND yes, The phase difference——   We switch on the battery the EMF is applied BUT, The current does not flow yet.... as we are taking a battery, The maximum EMF and Current it can apply is at sine 90. And after that it stays there , and current begins to flow fully.   In the case of AC, The current never flows.

Rofaida Elsayed You know when we derive these relations step by step , sine of 90 comes in place.   Have you seen this formula?...  I= I(max) x Sin(theta) E= E(max) x Sin(90+theta) in the case of inductor  And  I= I(max) x Sin(theta) E= E(max) x Sin(90 minus theta) in the case of Capacitor.  Note that when ever the voltage or current is alternating, the ‘theta’ always changes  Have you done the ‘Impedence Triangle’ That is all related with the phase difference. Rofaida Elsayed well its all the same in any voltage.  Just think of it like this , when Current in DC begins to rise, it acts as the 1/4th part of the AC current. Imagine 1 full cycle of AC graph till 2pie. Then imagine it till pie/2. And that is where the DC becomes constant. And after that, current flows through inductor.  It also makes sense as the phase shift is seen in sine of theta.  Theta keeps changing in ac. But in dc , the theta increases from zero to 90 and stays there. It makes sense as sine of 90 is also 1. Which could be the maximum value of current a dc circuit could ever have

Lag after switching devices off is caused by capacitors, not inductors. Mostly in switch-mode power supplies like phone chargers or computer PSUs. They have huge amounts of capacitance to smooth rectified ac power and internal transients. After the device is turned off, it acts as a small battery.

For low voltage over a longer distance transmission DC currents loose to much power at a much higher rate than AC and it's easier to manipulate. You can for instance change the Ampere flow by manipulating the so called "Reactive power" you can mantain the same amount of Watts (power) but lower the Ampere, so you can use a smaller cable  (thus a cheaper cable). For high voltage you usually use a DC current for long distance transmission, since it suffers less powerloss than an AC transmission. (And it's also cheaper :P)  It's not easy to explain over a text :P But you can read alot about AC and DC on Wikipedia :)

To address your question about how much harder does AC circuit analysis can get? Well it can get considerably more complex than what is given here. The description of RMS is quite simplified, and as the frequency goes up, circuit analysis can no longer be done assuming lumped component values. As you might imagine this becomes complex very quickly, so we now use complex computer tools to solver these types of designs. This is why today's cell phones exist, if you had to design one without the computer tools, it would take decades.

Brian McConkey How about electromagnetism as a whole? I'm specifically immensely interested in the electromagnetic side, so these types of circuits, induced currents, and magnetic fields. How do those play later in the game? Does the math get heavier? Because as you've said, a lot of engineers use computers for the more complex stuff, so is there ever a time where the human is actually doing the calculus? Applying Maxwell's Equations ourselves? That's what I'm particularly interested in.

APresidentsRansom Having just taken my engineering electronics course last semester, I can tell you, the math certainly ramps up.  Upper level use of AC circuitry requires in-depth knowledge of differential equations; while computers and calculators can help, if you can't do it on your own, you won't understand what the computer gives you.  Even then, there are some equations too hard for most computers to solve anyway which would be much more effectively solved by hand.  Remember: a computer is only as smart as its user!

So I'm not sure how to interpret your question of "does the math get heavier". I'm going to have to say yes, as we look more closely at the components and how the physical laws interact with the material that the components are made up of the math gets considerably more complex. The use of calculus and differential equations to solve the more complex configurations is definitely required, and as a student you will have to learn how to do this type of calculation. As for doing this while on the job, not so much. Being employed as an engineer you have to understand the physics but you have to be able to produce answers quickly and most importantly on a budget. Thus there is rarely time for solving complex math day in and day out. Having said that then I also have to say, once in a while you do have to go into detail and be able to solve complex questions, like can we use this inductor that was designed to operate at 20 KHz in our cell phone transmitter operating at 2.5 GHz (not a realistic question, but hopefully you get the point).
Brian McConkey Yes, I see now. Thank you very much on the insight!!!

@APresidentsRansom Engineers do not learn electricity and magnetism in the same depth as physicists ; if thats what interests you, it is its own field that can be studied for an entire lifetime. We are actually now looking for electromagnetic quantum critical points. Besides that point, in engineering (I am just about done with my mechanical engineering degree and physics degree), the math is actually simplified a whole lot. Partial differential equations are not attempted by hand by engineers, and the solutions are numerically and empirically solved;  PDEs and different vector spaces is what governs EnM. In engineering, you will stick with Ordinary Differential Equations (simple ones at that), complex analysis (not as complex as it sounds), and numerical methods using the computer (this method is used the most).

777Ime Yes, this has been sort of a dilemma for me recently on whether I want engineering or physics. I could see that my thoughts and aspirations lie more on the physics side. +Brian McConkey +APresidentsRansom Both of you need to keep in mind that electronics design is one relatively small subfield of Electrical Engineering. There are a CRAPTON of other subfields that are doing just fine in the US thank you very much. Power engineering continues to exist, and that field seems to be hurting for engineers (few are interested in it). There are also a large number of automation engineers (a field which is unlikely to see any shrinkage for a long time). Many engineers seem to be landing in programming jobs these days.  Most of my fellow students got multiple job offers before they graduated. I locked in a position before I got to my senior year.  Also bear in mind that most mechanical engineering students these days seem to be pushing for their masters to get maximum employment. I don't know why exactly, since I was a EE rather than an ME, but it means that you'll potentially be doing another 2 years of university. That may not be a deal-breaker, but it's something to keep in mind.

+APresidentsRansom Physics and most engineering fields are all degrees in specific kinds of applied mathematics. At least for EE, after freshman year, almost every course you take will either expose you to a whole new field of mathematics, or push your algebra and calculus skills to the max. EM specifically requires good knowledge of vector calculus, differential equations, and a bit of harmonic analysis (via fourier series).  A good way (but not the only way) to specialize in EM is to major in EE (specializing in power engineering) with a minor in Physics (specializing in E&M). You'll get to see electromagnetism from two VERY different angles.

Falcrist Interesting. And yes, vector calculus, differential equations, and harmonic analysis are DEFINITELY my favorite tools of math to use, and is why EM is so interesting to me. The "electronics" side isn't too amazing to me, and is why the physics side of it gets me. I honestly just want a career that'll enable me to apply these as much as I can, while also being able to do something "useful" like how an engineer is. Because studying the same formulas all my life won't get me a career.

I think we're all allowed to be a little hypocritical. :)  And I would argue that a "lie to children" is a very different and altogether much nastier breed.  Instead of "This is complicated so I'll simplify for ease of discussion" what I consider to be a true "Lie To Children" is more along the lines of, "This is complicated, and I don't want you getting any ideas, so I'll pretend it is simple."  Which is something you encounter a lot in more philosophical and/or sociological topics, and not really in the hard sciences. Which is basically a really pedantic way of saying, I don't think that CC is simplifying because they don't think much of their audience.  I think they're simplifying because ain't nobody got time for the complete and accurate models.

This is not how "lie to children" is used. I didn't make this term up; making up your own interpretation to argue from to insist that I'm wrong doesn't help the discussion. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lie-to-children Saying something isn't described by term X and then presenting your alternative as exactly the commonly accepted definition of X is not helpful.

000xyz nah dude I’m an electrical engineer, for ac circuits this is useless, if you want to do AC stuff, you have to make sure you know things from DC theory like node voltage, mesh current, thevenin/norton, delta wye, then you have to learn phasors, and you to understand steady state in DC for RLC circuits, then you can learn complex impedance which treats Ls and Cs as resistors in the frequency domain and do everything I said above as complex resistors. So instead of V=iR, it’s V=iZ, its not hard but you have to go through all that stuff, if you don’t know diff eq theory or linear algebra, you need to learn that as well bc problems can turn into second order diff eq systems, good luck

chicken bro There's no such thing as instantaneous change of velocity for objects with mass, as that would require infinite acceleration, which in turn requires either infinite force or zero mass. You can come arbitrarily close to instantaneous changes in velocity with arbitrarily large forces, but you can never overcome this fundamental property of mass. It's this fundamental property that the person in the video was talking about.  Inertia; it's not just a good idea, it's the law!

take physics or some intro circuits class and then come back  ...but/or...she is talking about three common components and these components were well explained in earlier videos in this segment.  These are key details as to how they behave in ac (as opposed to dc) circuits.  Sooooo, you could probably understand this video by re-watching the videos on electrochemistry and circuits.  (Understanding this allows you to do a bunch of useful stuff like create logic gates or understand why we have transformers on telephone poles)... (also understanding how capacitors work allows one to make super simple timers with only a few components...I didn't know how they worked in high school but it was useful for doing silly things with little breadboard circuits...could probably impress your teachers) (a resistor adds resistance (think V=IR), an inductor opposes change (think that the magnetic field coils around a straight current carrying wire so in a coil of wire the magnetic field resists itself), a capacitor stores energy(similar to an inductor but lets it out in a burst (capacitors are made up of two plates and an insulating material and build up charge on the first plate until the voltage difference is great enough to jump from plate to plate).)  This isn't a great answer(drunk and see lots of misspelled things) but perhaps it will provide some incite.  This is typically covered in one's second semester physics class in college in the US.
